metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Respondent No. 1 (Election Petition No. 320 of 1952)

facts.text: Lucknow Central Constituency is a double-member constituency, one seat reserved for Scheduled Castes.
Polling took place on 31-1-1952, and the two appellants were declared elected having secured the largest number of votes.
Respondent filed election petition under S.81 of Representation of the People Act, 1951 on June 10, 1952, alleging corrupt practices by appellants and praying for declaration of election void.
Appellants filed written statements denying allegations: first appellant on December 15, 1952; second on December 20, 1952.
Respondent No.4 (defeated candidate) filed written statement on December 3, 1952, alleging appellants obtained services of village officers like Lambardars and Sarpanches.
Respondent No.9 adopted Respondent No.4's allegations, adding Mukhias.
Respondent filed replication on January 10, 1953, alleging government servants worked for appellants, issued appeals, became polling agents.
Appellants objected to replication on January 24, 1953.
Appellants applied for preliminary hearing of issues on vagueness on January 24, 1953; heard February 25 and August 25, 1953.
Tribunal order on October 31, 1953: Para 7(c) not vague, remains; replication new matters disregarded; petitioner to supply names of officials.
Respondent applied for amendment of para 7(c) on February 27, 1953, to add village headmen (Mukhias) names, that they worked, issued appeals, became polling agents.
Respondent No.4 applied January 22, 1953 for additional issues on village officers assistance.
Tribunal dismissed Respondent No.4's application November 10, 1953; allowed respondent's amendment November 28, 1953, holding particulars of para 7(c), O.VI r.17 CPC applicable.

Election Tribunal judgment March 23, 1955: by majority, set aside election - (1) appellants obtained assistance of four Mukhias contravening s.123(8); (2) first appellant employed Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande exceeding Rule 118/Schedule VI, infringing s.123(7).

Para 7(c) of original petition: Respondents 1 and 2 could enlist support of government servants; details of eye relief camps at Kakori on Dec 16, 1951 and Dec 27, 1951 used for propaganda, attended by officials, creating impression of support.
Ganga Prasad engaged by first appellant to prepare three carbon copies of Electoral Rolls, paid Rs.550 at Re.0-8-0 per 100 voters.
Viswanath Pande engaged to enter voters' names in printed cards, paid Rs.275 at Re.0-4-0 per 100 cards; both expenses shown in return under item K.

legal_issues.text: Whether Tribunal had power under s.83(3) or O.VI r.17 CPC to allow amendment to para 7(c) introducing specific allegation of obtaining assistance of four named Mukhias under s.123(8).
Whether original para 7(c) sufficiently pleaded charge under s.123(8).
Whether Tribunal's finding on s.123(8) sustainable given amendment issue.
Whether first appellant employed Ganga Prasad and Viswanath Pande for payment in connection with election exceeding limit under Rule 118/Schedule VI, contravening s.123(7).

petitioner_arguments.text: Charge of employing four Mukhias not pleaded originally, introduced only by amendment Nov 28, 1953; Tribunal had no power under s.83(3) to allow as it adds new instances/charge; even under O.VI r.17, barred as fresh petition time-barred.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act s.81,83(3); CPC O.VI r.17; time limit under s.81 r.119

petitioner_arguments.text: Original para 7(c) vague, does not allege actual enlistment/assistance, only 'could enlist'; no list of particulars.
No evidence of contract of employment for Ganga Prasad/Viswanath Pande; piece-rate work, not employees.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.123(7), Rule 118, Schedule VI; distinction contract for services vs of service

petitioner_arguments.text: O.VI r.17 not applicable to pre-trial stages; s.90(2) limited; s.92 excludes it.

respondent_arguments.text: Amendment under s.83(3) merely particulars of original charge in para 7(c) that appellants could enlist support of govt servants, actually did via Mukhias.
Alternatively, power under O.VI r.17 CPC via s.90(2); trial includes pre-hearing; amendment discretion.
Ganga Prasad/Viswanath Pande employed for payment on piece-work basis, counts towards limit.

court_reasoning.text: s.83(3) allows amendment/enlargement of particulars including new instances if relate to ground/charge in petition (s.123 corrupt practices via s.100(2)(b)).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction: grounds (s.81/s.100/123 categories) vs material facts (s.83(1)) vs particulars (s.83(2)); new instances ok if fit ground.

court_reasoning.text: s.90(2) applies CPC procedure to entire trial (from transfer under s.86 to award), including pre-hearing like amendments; not excluded by s.83(3) (limited to particulars) or s.92.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial = whole proceedings; procedure includes amendment power.

court_reasoning.text: But O.VI r.17 power cannot permit new grounds/charges if fresh petition barred (s.81 time limit); subject to Act provisions.
Original para 7(c) does not clearly plead s.123(8): 'could enlist' â‰  'did enlist/assist'; vague, no actual assistance alleged; amendment introduces new charge, radically alters petition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Corrupt practice charges quasi-criminal, must be clear/precise.

court_reasoning.text: Amendment delayed, unexplained; indefensible in election context needing despatch.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if power, no sound discretion.

court_reasoning.text: Set aside amendment order Nov 28, 1953; reverse s.123(8) finding.
No evidence of employment contract for Ganga Prasad/Viswanath Pande; mere piece-work statement insufficient; distinction contract for services (independent) vs of service (employee).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on respondent; facts show contract work, not employment.

holdings.text: Tribunal power under s.83(3) includes new instances of corrupt practices if ground pleaded; under O.VI r.17 via s.90(2) for amendments generally, but not new charges if time-barred.
Original para 7(c) insufficient to plead s.123(8) charge; amendment beyond power.
No proof of employment under s.123(7); piece-rate not necessarily employment.

precedents_cited.relevance: Particulars of corrupt practices need not be in petition body if charge/ground stated; can be ordered later.
Similar to Beal v. Smith on particulars.
Allow amendment adding facts recently known for purity of election.
Utmost latitude to amend unless withheld info.
Tribunal power under s.90(2) for pre-hearing like adding parties (O.I rr.9,10,13).
s.90(2) procedure wider; power to amend petition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheo Mahadeo Prasad v. Deva Sharan
precedents_cited.relevance: Erroneous view s.83(3) excludes O.VI r.17.
Amendment power subject to time limit; no new charge if barred.
No amendment adding new charge post-limitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for contract of employment: personal labour.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs election petitions, corrupt practices, amendment of particulars, Tribunal procedure and powers.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied via s.90(2) for trial procedure including amendments; powers under s.92 for specified matters.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, set aside Tribunal's order of amendment dated November 28, 1953, reversed finding of corrupt practice under s.123(8) re Mukhias, and held no evidence for s.123(7) violation re extra employment, effectively restoring the election.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; Tribunal's judgment and order dated March 23, 1955 set aside on both grounds.

key_quotes.text: "s.83(3) is intended to clothe the Tribunal with a general power to allow not merely an amendment of particulars already given but also inclusion of fresh particulars, pleading new instances, subject to the condition that they are in respect of a ground set out in the petition."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of amendment power under s.83(3).

key_quotes.text: "The Tribunal has power under O.VI r.17 to order amendment of a petition, but that power cannot be exercised so as to permit new grounds or charges to be raised... if a fresh petition on those allegations will then be barred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits O.VI r.17 in election petitions due to time bar.

key_quotes.text: "There is in law a well-established distinction between a contract for services, and a contract of service."
key_quotes.speaker: court
